1) Support in core improvement of the lawmaking and rulemaking basis provided through development of the new edition of the Law on Normative Legal Acts. 2) Piloting of the Regulatory Impact Assessment tools and mechanisms of the Smart Regulation System were conducted in cooperation with national partners. 3) Draft legal act on further improvement of the civic engagement into the lawmaking process was elaborated. Mechanisms for efficient and timely implementation of the Law on Public Control were developed and provided to the national partners. 4) The recommendations provided by the Project are considered in the rulemaking process of the MFA.

1) The first draft of methodology and procedures on regulatory impact assessment were developed. The formal public discussions over procedures of regulatory impact assessment have been initiated .
The draft Presidential decree of further steps on introduction of comprehensive system of regulatory impact assessment is exposed for public discussion (https://regulation.gov.uz/ru/document/7837). The draft Presidential Decree is one of the key outputs of the RIA project. The decree is aimed at gradual integration of the legal mechanisms of regulatory impact assessment into day to day practice of the Government agencies and Parliament. The scope of regulatory impact assessment will be expanding every year, covering: ● in 2020 - draft laws only; ● starting from the 1 January 2021 – all draft legal acts, including those developed by ministries and other government agencies; ● starting from 1 of September, 2021 – ex-ante impact assessment of the legislative. initiatives should be conducted prior including them into annual plan of legislative activities.
The draft of a new revision of the law “On normative and legal acts” was developed within the project framework. That law is a backbone of the lawmaking and rulemaking system in Uzbekistan. It definses all the processes and stages of preparinf, approving and adopting all types of legals acts. The ndraft new revision developed by the project contains a number of progressive novels, establishing RIA as a mandatory procedure to be conducted before the legal initiative turns into a draft legal act, establishing anticorruption screening of legal acts as a separate mandatory procedure, setting negative RIA results as a barrier for including legal initiative into a rulemaking and lawmaking plans. The draft new revision of the law was adopted in first reading at the legislative chamber of the Oliy Majlis. There are two readings ahead.
2) Four expert groups were established to pilot regulatory impact assessment procedures and methodology, uniting over 30 experts. Four expert groups are gathered under umbrella of the Legislation and Parliamentary Research Institute to perform ex-ante assessment of the draft laws “On beekeeping”, “On craftsmanship”, recently adopted Administrative Procedures Act, and expected impact after reduction of VAT rate. Project team plans to improve the draft Presidential Decree considering the results of public discussions and piloting. - International expert have conducted the first part of the training on practice of regulatory impact assessment for civil servants. 56 public servants were participating in training on practice of regulatory impact assessment organized by the RIA-2 Project. The 4-day training was delivered by international expert. Out of 56 public servans 33 have successfully passed the examination test (including 11 women) from 10 public agencies & ministries. The DVDs with training materials were distributed among training participants. The DVD format improves the usability of training and for civil servants.
3) Experts to analyse the legislative activities of the executive and legislative branches, as well as to develop policy papers on the gaps and constraints in performing civic/public and parliamentary oversight functions and improvement of the certain legal environment and mechanisms are hired. Concept notes are being developed for discussions. The research on civic engagement is in progress. Based on the results of the research findings the recommendations will be prepared and discussed with wide audience and government agencies.
4) Due to cuts in project budget, the support provided to MFA was limited. The study on assessment of the impact anticipated after ratification of the UN Convention on dry ports is in progress. The results will be presented to MFA for consideration.

1) Support the efforts of national partners in promoting improved lawmaking processes and anticorruption expertise. Expected output: -National partners are provided with information and understanding of the costs of deployment of regulatory impact assessment system through analytical papers and results of piloting RIA.
2) Support the development of short term training courses on RIA and anticorruption expertise. Expected output: National partners are provided with training for training module on regulatory impact assessment and receive the first group of trainers prepared for further spread of experience and knowledge of conducting the RIA and anticorruption expertise.
3) Contribute to improvement of the mechanisms of parliamentary oversight and civic engagement to lawmaking processes. National partners are provided with recommendations on further improvement of the legal and normative base on parliamentary and civic oversight.

The following key results were achieved within the framework of the implementation of the first component in providing legal support for reforms and coordinating the legislative process: • Recommendations for improving the rule-making have been developed. 80% have been used in Decree No.5505. • Amended draft law On normative legal acts has been developed. • Recommendations for improving public control mechanisms have been prepared (PD-5980). • An assessment of regulatory impact has been carried out and recommendations have been prepared to optimize the legal framework. • Draft decision of the President of Uzbekistan on the approval of a program of measures for the use of international indices as a guideline for the priority development and implementation of reforms.
As part of the implementation of the second component to help improve the quality of the development of regulations and the introduction of full-fledged RIA tools: • Assistance was provided in the inventory of normative legal acts in the field of entrepreneurship (more than 600 NLAs) and recommendations were prepared on the application of the regulatory guillotine (No.PR-5997). 29 PDs=>Laws, 59 CMRs and acts of ministries=>Laws. • Estimated cost of deployment and operation of RIA mechanisms and training of civil servants (RIA of 2000 NLAs requires about 103 billion soum per a year, and additional 2.2 billion soum for training). • Training was held on application of the regulatory guillotine and the establishment of interaction with society. 3 trainings were held on application of regulatory impact assessment methods. 94 civil servants were trained. Of these, 75 (80%) trainees, including 11 trainers, successfully passed the final testing and received certificates. A module was developed for training on anti-corruption review of legal normative acts for the Academy of the General Prosecutorʼs Office. A mobile application has been developed to involve citizens in crime prevention activities.
As part of the implementation of the third component to build the capacity of the Oliy Majlis to consider bills in accordance with international standards and implement parliamentary oversight: • RIA methodology and the corresponding draft decision of the President were developed (jointly with Institute for Legislative Problems and Parliamentary Studies (LPRI). • Public consultations were held. • the Methodology was piloted jointly with LPRI, UWED Center, CERR and NGO Mano to assess the regulatory impact. • Analysis of the mechanisms of involving citizens in the rule-making process was carried out. The reasons for the insufficient participation of citizens in rule-making were studied through such tools as MeningFikrim.uz and regulation.gov.uz. websites. • Seminars were held on the role of Parliament in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. Recommendations: • on mechanisms for systematizing parliamentary control over achievement of SDGs; • on using SDG indicators in the development of political party programs; • on establishing parliamentary institutions to monitor the SDGs achievement. • Recommendations for improving the legal mechanisms of public control were prepared (used in No.PR-5980).
As part of the implementation of the fourth component to promote the improvement of the mechanism for the implementation of international treaties and the legal framework of foreign policy and international activities of Uzbekistan. • Analysis of the challenges and advantages of Uzbekistanʼs accession to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. • Discussion of mechanisms for improving the legal framework in the field of energy diplomacy. • Assessment of potential impact of the ratification of the interstate agreement on dry ports. • Recommendations for establishment of a system of inventory and monitoring of the implementation of international treaties in national legislation (PD-6075).
The project focuses solely on providing analytical and expert support. Thus, despite the limited financial possibilities, the Project seeks to maximize the positive effect of assistance through an increased quality of regulatory decisions made by national partners
